üö¢ Industry Update: P&O Exit and what that means for New Zealand: Carnival Corporation announced last week that P&O Cruises Australia will be shut down in March 2025 and integrated into Carnival Cruise Line, owned by global ship operator Carnival Corporation. CEO Josh Weinstein said the decision was made because of the South Pacific‚Äôs small population as well as ‚Äúsignificantly higher operating and regulatory costs‚Äù. This decision was influenced by increasing operational costs and stricter regulations here in New Zealand and our region, which has become one of the most expensive destinations for cruise ships to operate in. Issues such as higher port fees, local and central government levies and rising destination costs are starting to tip the balance against the viability of operating lines like P&O in the region. Another significant issue mentioned was biofouling and the lack of hull cleaning facilities to enable ships to comply. Ships coming from Australia face challenges in maintaining cleanliness due to the lack of intermediate cleaning stations en route to New Zealand. "Given the strategic reality of the South Pacific's small population and significantly higher operating and regulatory costs, we're adjusting our approach to give us the efficiencies we need to continue delivering an incredible cruise experience year-round to our guests in the region,‚Äù said Weinstein. The Pacific Explorer will be retired after next February, while the Pacific Encounter and Pacific Adventure ships will be rebranded. We and the wider industry, are expressing concerns over the potential for other cruise companies to follow P&O Cruises Australia's path.Amidst intensified global competition, the smaller size of the Australasian cruise market, and logistical challenges of managing price fluctuations within a season when cruise prices are set years in advance contribute to these strategic changes. While New Zealand continues to rate highly for passenger experiences, as an industry and nation, we need to take this decision seriously and remember that cruise lines have a choice of where they will operate, meaning the growth of cruise and financial benefits to our economy and regions is by no means guaranteed. https://lnkd.in/gvrT6T7w #NZCA #CruiseNews #WeAreCruise #NZCruiseIndustry #CruiseNZ #Carnival #TourismNZ #MaritimeIndustry #NewZealand

Not content with trying to wreck the climate with an airline, Branson wants to wreck it with a cruise line. Cruise ships are perfect examples of late stage fossil capitalism - towering behemoths that pour pollution into the air and into the sea. They are often a blight on communities as these ships are able to dispense thousands of marauding tourists into historic towns designed to accommodate hundreds. They poison the air with fumes from diesel engines running on heavy fuel, even when docked as they use them to generate electricity. They produce town-sized carbon dioxide emissions. There are much larger cruise lines which produce much bigger impacts - Carnival Cruises for example - but Branson's attempt to make cruising "cool" represents an attempt to pull even more people into this destructive sector.

Despite these changes, New Zealand continues to rate highly for passenger experiences, affirming our commitment to exceptional service amidst evolving market dynamics. üåü As we bid farewell to the iconic P&O, which has served Australasia for 90 years, we look forward to adapting and thriving in this competitive landscape.
